Thought you might like to see a few photos I snapped at the Inauguration of President Donald J. Trump (presented in chronological order, from left to right, top to bottom).  First, the Capitol Building from my office window the night before.  Although the media would have you believe differently, many Democrats did attend the event.  In fact, I was sitting next to Democrat John Larson from Connecticut (with a beard) and fellow Republican Robert Aderholt from Alabama.  More Democrats at the event: President Carter and President and Secretary Clinton.  It was also good to see President George W. and Laura Bush.  And obviously, the outgoing Administration was present, beginning with Michelle Obama and Jill Biden, and followed by President Obama and Vice President Biden.   You could really feel the excitement of the crowd build as the inaugural procession began.  Here is Speaker of the House Paul Ryan, followed by Vice President Mike Pence.  And of course, the crowd erupted as President Trump appeared.    All in all, it was an exciting day in our nation's capital.  I thought President Trump delivered a unifying message in his address, pledging to fight for a nation and a federal government that works for all Americans.  He offered a vision of an America where everyone has an opportunity to share in its successes and no one is left behind.  I look forward to working with him and my colleagues on both sides of the aisle to achieve these bold, optimistic goals.

On our way back to Cincinnati from the Inauguration, my wife Donna and I stopped by my alma mater, the College of William & Mary in Williamsburg, Virginia.  While there, I took this selfie in front of the Sir Christopher Wren Building on campus.  Built between 1695 and 1700, the Wren Building is the oldest American college building still in use.  The design of the building has been attributed to famed English mathematician and architect,  Sir Christopher Wren, hence its name.  Wren is best known for rebuilding much of London after the great fire in 1666.  The most renowned structure Wren rebuilt during that period was St. Paul's Cathedral, to which Wren added a dome which was, in turn, the inspiration for the dome of the U.S. Capitol Building.    I also snapped this photo of a statue in Williamsburg of Thomas Jefferson drafting the Declaration of Independence.  The connection?  Jefferson lived in the Wren Building while a student at William & Mary.  Jefferson attended William & Mary a few years before I did.

Here's a photo of Cincinnati's two state championship football teams -- St. Xavier High School in Division I and my alma mater Cincinnati La Salle High School in Division II.  What makes their championships so unique is that they not only share a league (the GCL South), but the two schools are located on the same road (North Bend Road), just down the street from each other.    The picture below shows each school's coach (Steve Specht at St. X, and Jim Hilvert at La Salle -- although Coach Hilvert recently accepted the head coaching position at Baldwin Wallace University in Berea, Ohio), surrounded by a number of players.   Again, congratulations to both schools, their coaches, players, students and all their supporters.  You've made all of us in Cincinnati proud.

Valentine's Day is just around the corner, so for #ThrowbackThursday, here's a photo of my mom and dad, shortly after my dad returned from the war.  They met at a USO dance in Charlotte, North Carolina, where my dad was stationed at the time, and my mom grew up.  After my dad returned from the war in Europe, they were married in Charlotte, and moved to Massachusetts where they lived for a year (my dad's family was there).  A job opening brought them to Cincinnati (where they didn't know anyone).  Over the years, they would have four kids, including me.  They were married for 52 years when my dad passed away back in 1998, and my mom is now 92 and doing well.  Happy Valentine's Day!  #TBT

Opening Day was last week and the Cincinnati Reds are on fire - let's hope they can keep the momentum.  So for #ThrowbackThursday, here's a photo from 30 years ago - 1987.  Here's the story behind it.  As all Cincinnatians know, the Reds were the first professional baseball team.  And in recognition of that, the Reds played the first game each year.  Well, the Toronto Blue Jays tried to muscle in on that tradition, and the city councils of Toronto and Cincinnati got into a verbal clash, and jointly decided that we'd settle the score with a friendly baseball game between the two city councils.  I was on Cincinnati City Council at the time, and we travelled to Toronto, played the game in Blue Jays Stadium before a real game, and got our butts kicked.  Anyway from left to right, back row: David Mann (whom I would defeat 7 years later to be elected to Congress), Mayor Charlie Luken, Ken Blackwell's son Rashad, Ken Blackwell, Jim Cissell, the late Pete Strauss, the late John Mirlisena (whom I would defeat for Hamilton County Commissioner 3 and again 5 years later), Guy Guckenberger, and front row left to right: Arn Bortz, me, and channel 12 reporter Steve Langford (his shirt says "city newshound").  GO REDS!  #TBT

This afternoon, I had the honor of presenting the Carnegie Medal to Rev. Timothy Carpenter, who was injured trying to save the life of a 60 year old woman in 2015.  The woman, who was bound to a wheelchair, was viciously attacked from behind by a young man with a knife.  When Rev. Carpenter saw the attack, he leapt into action.  He was able to disarm the assailant and stop the attack, but sadly the woman died from her wounds at the scene.    The Carnegie Medal is awarded by the Carnegie Hero Fund Commission to individuals who display "outstanding acts of selfless heroism" and "risk their lives to an extraordinary degree to save or attempt to save the lives of others."  Rev. Carpenter's actions epitomize the award, and we are fortunate to have individuals like him living in our community.  Thank you and congratulations, Rev. Carpenter.  And God bless you and your family!

On Memorial Day, I marched in the parade in Cleves and spoke at the dedication of the community's memorial to Sgt. David Kreuter.  Sgt. Kreuter grew up on Cincinnati's westside, and he graduated from St. Xavier High School and the University of Cincinnati.  He joined the U.S. Marine Reserves in 1998, and proudly served our nation until his tragic death in Iraq on August 3, 2005. On that fateful day, he was one of 14 marines killed when their transport vehicle hit a roadside bomb.  Sgt. Kreuter believed that hard work, preparation and a good education were the necessary components of a successful life, a belief reflected in his dedication to his duties. He was also a proud American, and cared deeply for the freedoms he fought every day to protect as a Marine. Back in 1983, more than ten years before he became Speaker of the House, Congressman Newt Gingrich founded the Conservative Opportunity Society (COS).  It's a group of ten to twenty or so Members of Congress who meet weekly. I've been an active member for over two decades now.    We have a guest speaker each week.  Our speaker last week was Laura Ingraham. My mom has a birthday today.  Doris Leona Tilley (Chabot) was born on July 16, 1924 and turns 93 today.  She and her late husband, Gerard Joseph Chabot, met during WWII at a USO dance in her hometown, Charlotte, North Carolina.  After he came back from the war, they got married, moved to his hometown in Massachusetts for a year, and then to Cincinnati.  Their first two sons were born when they lived in a trailer park in Reading (I was the second son, after my brother Ron, and we lived in a trailer until I was 6 years old).  Then we moved to an apartment in Price Hill for 3 years where my sister Carol was born.  Then to our first house in Westwood, where our brother Dave was born.  After we four kids were raised, my mom would work over the years for Shillito's and McAlpin's Department Stores in Western Hills, Dr. Williams and Borroughs pediatricians in Delhi, and volunteer at St. Francis St. George Hospital in Western Hills.  She's always been a big Cincinnati Reds fan, and loves to read.  She is a special lady.

My history with the sugar program goes way back to my first term in Congress, when then-Congressman Senator Chuck Schumer and I introduced legislation to eliminate all federal sugar subsidies. In the subsequent period of time, my distaste for sugar subsidies hasn’t mellowed at all.  The entire federal sugar program is written in a way to artificially inflate sugar prices.  As a result, the sugar program raises the price of sugar that we pay domestically. In recent years, I’ve voted to support the modernization of the sugar program, and today I am proud to support Representative Virginia Foxx’s legislation, which will help to restore market principles to the sugar industry by getting rid of artificial subsidies and governmental interference.
